revision_content.description: Understand the basics of probability—how likely events are to happen, using simple experiments, fractions, and logic.

subtopics.title: Basic Probability
subtopics.definition: Probability is the measure of how likely an event is to happen, ranging from 0 (impossible) to 1 (certain).

example.question: A bag has 3 red and 2 blue balls. What is the probability of picking a red ball?

subtopics.whyItMatters: Probability helps us make informed decisions in real life—from sports to weather forecasts to gambling odds.
quickTips: You can express it as a fraction, decimal, or percentage.

subtopics.title: Equally Likely Outcomes
subtopics.definition: Events where each possible outcome has the same chance of happening.

example.question: When tossing a fair coin, what is the chance of getting heads?

subtopics.whyItMatters: Understanding fairness helps you know when experiments are unbiased.
quickTips: Always check if the experiment is fair.
Don’t assume outcomes are equally likely—check the setup.

subtopics.title: Impossible and Certain Events
subtopics.definition: An impossible event has a probability of 0; a certain event has a probability of 1.

example.question: What’s the probability of rolling a 7 on a 6-sided die?

subtopics.whyItMatters: Knowing extremes helps set the boundaries of possibility.
quickTips: Nothing can have a probability less than 0 or more than 1.
Use common sense—don’t overthink impossible outcomes.

subtopics.title: Listing Outcomes (Sample Space)
subtopics.definition: All the possible results of a probability experiment.
subtopics.whyItMatters: Knowing all possible outcomes helps calculate accurate probabilities.
quickTips: Use a tree diagram or table to list complex sample spaces.
Sample space = total number of outcomes.

subtopics.title: Experimental vs Theoretical Probability
subtopics.definition: Theoretical is calculated using math; experimental is based on actual results from trials.

example.question: If you toss a coin 10 times and get heads 6 times, what's the experimental probability of heads?

subtopics.whyItMatters: Theoretical helps predict, experimental tests reality.
quickTips: Larger number of trials gives more accurate experimental results.
Compare both to spot bias or errors.

subtopics.title: Simple Events with Dice and Coins
subtopics.definition: Calculating the chance of outcomes in basic experiments like tossing coins or rolling dice.

example.question: Probability of rolling an even number on a dice?

subtopics.whyItMatters: Common in exams and builds intuition for harder questions.
quickTips: Always count favorable and total outcomes.
Use symmetry—dice and coins are balanced.

subtopics.title: Mutually Exclusive Events
subtopics.definition: Events that cannot happen at the same time.

example.question: Chance of rolling a 2 or a 5?

subtopics.whyItMatters: This is the first step toward adding probabilities correctly.
quickTips: Check if events can overlap. If not, they’re exclusive.

subtopics.title: Complementary Events
subtopics.definition: Events that cover all outcomes together (one happens if the other doesn’t).

example.question: If chance of rain is 0.3, what’s the chance it won’t rain?

subtopics.whyItMatters: Helps you find missing probabilities easily.
quickTips: The sum of complementary events is always 1.
Use this trick to double-check answers.
